author: ajsutton
content:
Right so the shadow fork went extremely well.  Prior to the merge, both Prysm and Nimbus had some issues handling the huge stream of deposits that were being processed. Prysm was generating blocks very late causing a lot of missed head votes and low sync committee participation. Nimbus was producing invalid blocks.  Neither issue was related to the merge and both have been fixed. Just goes to show that all the best clients have issues with deposits - not sure why Lighthouse and Lodestar haven't caught on to that yet...

The actual merge went through fine despite those issues and having so many late blocks.  Now that both issues have been fixed we're seeing really high participation for attestations and sync committees. It's a very healthy looking chain.

author: ajsutton
content: There are also a few nodes still syncing the EL which has given us a good test of optimistic sync.  In particular some nodes had the CL in sync prior to the merge but the EL not yet sync'd.  It's not safe to optimistically import the transition block straight away (it's a whole thing, just trust me...) so these nodes *stop* optimistic import when the transition block is found and can't import any further blocks until its safe to do so.  By default that safety threshold is set to 128 slots, so they fall 128 slots behind the chain head, then go back to optimistic syncing.  Seeing that actually work in the real world for both the EL and CL involved was a good outcome.

content: I proposed a block on the mainnet shadow fork 2 where priority fees were ~0.1 ETH, but the balance of the address is ~0.25 ETH. Where did the additional ETH come from?

author: experience_
content: This is the second shadow fork without any finalization issue. Participation rate seems much higher than the previous shadow fork. All clients seem to have gone through the merge without major hiccups. What is the next milestone before we can merge public testnets like Goerli?
